comments.author: Stephen Murgatroyd

comments.text:
Quick hydrodynamics fact. In the first trick, what's actually happening is 
a process called cavitation. As you strike the top of the bottle, a low 
pressure area is formed at the bottom of the bottle forming small void 
bubbles. As the high pressure forces down on the region, the bubbles 
collapse...well explode rather causing an immense amount of force on 
whatever surface it's touching. This also can happen in pipes an boat 
propellers. The mantis shrimp even uses this to get at it's prey!﻿

comments.author: Dana Ysabel Romano

comments.text:
Guys do this science experiment.

You will need; 1 glass bottle(beer or soda), note pad, writing utensil

Step 1: Remove all paper labels from the bottle

Step 2: Hold bottle at the neck like a hammer with the thicker end on top

Step 3: Hold the bottle over your head as if you are going to throw it

Step 4: Throw the bottle at a hard surface that won't break

Step 5: Observe any changes in the bottle and write them down in your note 
pad

I hope you enjoyed this science experiment.﻿

comments.author: Mathew Aldington

comments.text:
+Lee Peffers Yes you can, you could compress the gas. But it this case, 
that's not even necessary - it's not a closed system, the bottle is open.
There has to be a near vacuum created in this trick. The pressure 
differential between the vacuum and the air above the water is what causes 
the water to accelerate so rapidly, and as such, applying enough force to 
break the bottle as it slams into it.
comments.author: Andy Roberts

comments.text:
+KidSavesTheWorld -Again
You can't create a vacuum in an enclosed system that is 100% full...
comments.author: Lee Peffers

comments.text:
Of course it wouldn't be a perfect vacuum, but the much lower pressure 
there would "suck" in a sense. Think of it like wind, when there is a low 
pressure area of air, higher pressure air will go towards it to compensate
comments.author: KidSavesTheWorld -Again

comments.author: Kaitlyn Theresa

comments.text:
There's another one that I recently found. Basically, a lot of people want 
to break glasses with their voice. Well, if you want to do that, simply tap 
the glass with a spoon or your fingernail. The note it makes is the note 
you need to sing to break it. Bear in mind this is the easiest method but 
not the only one. If you create a resonant (full sounding) bass or baritone 
sound of the note you heard while tapping the glass, it will break, but 
this is far harder to pull off.﻿
comments.author: Bryce Jackson
